fields.description:
We are using atlassian-user.xml schema (we migrated from osuser). However, if we ever reinstall (for development or testing) we'd have to install the osuser schema and then go through the migration process from osuser to atlassian-user in order to user atlassian-user. As you might imagine, this is particularly a pain if you are just trying to setup a development environment and need to use atlassian-user (to make development mirror test and production environments).

It would be much easier if being able to select atlassian-user was part of the installer.

fields.description:
In JIRA's admin section, there is a "Support Request" link from which one can create a new support request on https://support.atlassian.com, with system info and optionally logs and (anonymized) data attached. See [this sample|^JirasupportRequest.html]. 

It would be great if Confluence had something similar.  Confluence problems that are system-related frequently require system info and logs to diagnose, and having this upfront often saves time.

Also, JIRA's support request page lets one enter the key of an existing support request. In long-running cases we frequently have to ask for updated logs and config files, and being able to do this from an admin screen would again save much time.
fields.summary: Create a support request page similar to JIRA

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-9198].
  {panel}

Our Atom (and RSS) feeds don't correctly identify multiple items about the same content.  This causes Feed Readers to override items about the same content in your reader.

To reproduce:
1. Create a Page
2. Edit this Page
3. Create a Feed on this Page

This results in the feed containing a create, then an edit item.  This is correct, but both items have the same link (uri/guid) which means the reader will only list one item in your inbox.

What should happen is up for comment but is expected to be two separate items in your reader: one for the create and one for each and every update.

To do this I believe we will need to generate different link or id/guid tags for each update.
fields.summary: Page Edits don't have unique Link tags

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-9192].
  {panel}

It would be really helpful if there was an automated nightly build service for https://svn.atlassian.com/svn/public/contrib/ projects.

Why it might make sense:

* The cost of setting up and maintaining the build environment would be outweighed by the showcasing of clover in a number of real projects to potential clover buyers, and if you use continuum there is no licensing cost.
* The quality of available maven plugins provided by the community (collaboration!) would increase through clover reporting in builds of those projects.
* You would have better quick insight into what is going on in community provided plugins through clover reporting of those projects, and could send out nag emails (if requested) when builds are broken thereby keeping developers of those plugins engaged in its development.
* You would incent more developers to become involved in plugin development for atlassian, because it would be cool.

One way to do this:

* Setup a server at atlassian (or use an existing one) that has nothing better to do to run continuum and make its reports publicly accessible (probably via publishing to some other server).
* Edit http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DEVNET/Developer+Subversion+Repository and tell people to talk to you if they are interested in this new service, and that they will have to upgrade their build to Maven 2 if they are interested. Also, send something out to confluence-developer@lists.atlassian.com saying the same.
* Information on how to do upgrade a maven 1 project to maven 2 is here. It may need a little work, but I'd be happy to assist in maintaining it or providing whatever info I can to help get people started: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DISC/Developing+Confluence+Plugins+with+Maven+2
* Tell developers to add a profile similar to the following to their pom.xml which would look for a clover license file that would only exist on the build server (for example, in the java.home dir) and only runs this profile if that license exists:

 <project>
   ...
  <profiles>
    <profile>
      <id>atlassian-nightly-build</id>
      <activation>
        <file>
          <exists>${java.home}/clover.license</exists>
        </file>
      </activation>
      ...
    </profile>
  </profiles>
  ...
</project>
fields.summary: Suggestion for hosted automated nightly build service for https://svn.atlassian.com/svn/public/contrib/ projects

fields.description:
The root cause of the defect CONF-9179 was that the pom was applying resource filtering to a gif. This led to a jar being built that contained a corrupt image file.

On Mac OS X this filtering has no affect on binary files. However on Windows it is a problem. I'm not sure about Linux but presumably being a *nix it also isn't a problem.

Therefore until we have a standard (non-Windows) build machine we need to protect ourselves by fixing such pom's. 

The leftnavigation theme is definitely affected, however it would also be worth checking across all our builds for safety.
fields.summary: Ensure we don't filter binary files in maven builds

fields.description:
After using a utility to read in ConfluenceActionSupport.properties and write it out I noticed the following messiness in ConfluenceActionSupport.properties: Line 1223: {code} rebuild.in.progress=Rebuild In Progress -+ -+-+-+-+-+-+-+ {code} the second two lines are interpreted by Java as: {code} -+= -+-+-+-+-+-+-+= {code} (which I'm sure was a mistake) The following comment needs to have # before every line, otherwise this: (line 5222) {code} #mysql.warning=If you are using MySQL, the JDBC URL for the connection must have \ ‘autoReconnect=true’ set. For example:

\ 
jdbc:mysql://localhost/confluence?autoReconnect=true
\

If the autoreconnect flag is not set, the MySQL JDBC driver will eventually time out, \ and Confluence will no longer be able to communicate with the database. If you plan to use non-latin characters, \ you will also need to add &useUnicode=true&characterEncoding=utf8 \ on the end of the above URL. These options are \ not required for any database other than MySQL. {code} produces an actual property: {code} ‘autoReconnect=true’ set. For example:

jdbc:mysql://localhost/confluence?autoReconnect=true

If the autoreconnect flag is not set, the MySQL JDBC driver will eventually time out, and Confluence will no longer be able to communicate with the datab\ ase. If you plan to use non-latin characters, you will also need to add &useUnicode=true&characterEncoding=utf8 on the end of the above URL. These options are not required for any database other than MySQL. {code} Finally, the following properties don't follow the lowercase naming scheme found in the rest of the properties. This might be good to clean up as part of 2.6, but since they could be being used by people, you may want to just leave them alone, even though they are ugly: {code} ADMINISTRATECONFLUENCE=Administer Confluence AbstractPageAction.space.key.empty=You must enter a value for space key. AbstractSetupEmailAction.name.empty=Name can''t be empty! COMMENT=Leave Comments CREATESPACE=Create Space EDITSPACE=Modify Space PROFILEATTACHMENTS=Attach Files to User Profile PageNotPermittedAction.action.cannot.view=You cannot view this page PageNotPermittedAction.action.cannot.view.description=Page level restrictions have been applied that limits access to this page. PageNotPermittedAction.action.cannot.view.inherited=You cannot view this page due to inherited restrictions PageNotPermittedAction.action.cannot.view.inherited.description=Page level restrictions have been applied to a parent of the current page. These restrictions limit access to only certain certain user(s) or group(s) and apply to all pages in the hierarchy underneath the parent. Please=note that only alphanumeric characters are allowed for variable names; no space or other special characters will be picked. SETSPACEPERMISSIONS=Administer Space See=also: global popular labels. USECONFLUENCE=Use Confluence VIEWSPACE=View Space {code}

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-9160].
  {panel}

In our environment blog-posts are used to collect the inputs for various newsletters, some of which are published daily, others weekly. The different newsletters are identified by labels, the most recent edition is displayed by a page containing something similar to {blog-posts:20|time=1d|labels=abc}.
It is required to be able to link directly to archived versions of newsletters; however, since news for several different newsletters can be posted on one specific date (not only those belonging to one selected newsletter) it is not sufficient to just use the link-format e.g. [/2007/07/15]. 
I would therefore suggest to extend the accepted format for the time-parameter such that also pprecise dates can be used.
I would furthermore appreciate if this change could also we applied to other macros using time as a selection criterion (e.g. search).

A customer has remarked on some problems with the "Upgrading Confluence" doc - see two comments here:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Upgrading+Confluence?focusedCommentId=78676329#comment-78676329

___________COMMENT 1______________

2. stop server
3. empty Database (MySQL)
4. move the content of /data/confluence/attachments (nearly 2 GB!) to outside of Server so that /attachments is empty(!)
5. deploy new confluence.war
6. start server
7. run setup with restore of backup from Step1.
8. move the content of /data/confluence/attachments back to the Server
9. run search index

This steps seems to lead to the right result. Some tests are required now. "
________________ COMMENT 2__________

"Method 1 on Windows should also mention running tomcat5w to remove and re-install the tomcat service, since the tomcat home (and hence the log directory) has changed."

fields.description:
[MySQL Storage Engine|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONF25/Known+Issues+for+MySQL#KnownIssuesforMySQL-MySQLStorageEngine]

The Default storage engine for MySQL is MyISAM. This storage engine does not support Foreign Key constraints. This may cause data corruption and is not recommended for use.

You can set the default Storage Engine for MySQL by passing the '--default-storage-engine=InnoDB' option when starting mysql.

For more information see: http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/4.1/en/storage-engines.html.

Can we possibly fix it via following [these instructions|http://www.hibernate.org/119.html#A8]?

* note : seems as the upgrade process is triggered twice under a specific circumstance - please investigate
fields.summary: InnoDB vs MyISAM discrepancy with MySQL

fields.description:
The steps to reproduce the error will create an environment that won't be common, but it may highlight a deficiency in the code to delete referrers from the admin section.

To reproduce the issue:

1. Access Confluence through a different URL to the standard URL (to trick pages into thinking that an incoming link is an external referrer). I edited my "hosts" file in Windows to point the address "test" to 127.0.0.1.
2. Create a comment on a page with a link to any page in Confluence.
3. Go to the comment permlink.
4. Follow the link in the comment to a page.
5. Check the Info tab of the target page and a referrer should have been added.
6. Ban this referrer.
7. In "Manage Referrers" of admin, you can't delete the newly banned referrer.

I confirmed that I could not delete the following referrer URLs:

1. http://test:8080/display/DEMO/Home?focusedCommentId=1933313#comment-1933313
2. http://test:8080/display/DEMO/Home?showComments=true&showCommentArea=true

Maybe the code is tripping over the question mark? There's no log errors.
fields.summary: Unable to delete banned referrers

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-9142].
  {panel}

When you remove a user in Confluence 2.5.4 massive, it states:
"Removing a user will remove all permission restrictions associated with him/her. Content that is only restricted to this user will become available to all confluence users. Are you sure you want to delete this user?"

The thing that scares me about this is "Content that is only restricted to this user will become available to all confluence users." One of the main reasons we bought Confluence was because certain documentation should be limited to one or more individuals.

If someone on our support team removes a user and by doing so opens up content that the user owned to everyone out there, this could expose sensitive information and cause huge headaches.

A suggested alternative to this (which would work for bulk user deletes also) would be to show a table (could be paged) of the following when an administrator tries to remove one or more users and those users have content that only they have permissions to:

Table column headings:
Userid - Page (or Object that users has sole permissions to) - Reassign to Group/User

Reassign to Group/User cells under heading would contain a dropdown with values: "User" and "Group" and then an empty text field with a "lookup" button next to it.

Then you could also have two links next to Reassign... for each row called "reassign all for user" (that will fill in the reassign field for all content solely owned by that user, and something at the top called "reassign all" (or similar) that lets you just bulk reassign everything (regardless of user who owns it) to a single user/group.

I know that sounds like a lot, but I think that is one way to do it more safely. You might also state something like "You should encourage your users to always have more than one person assigned to private content to avoid this page."
fields.summary: Suggest user removal method that is more secure than "Content that is only restricted to this user will become available to all confluence users"

fields.description:
Right now it is very dangerous and a possible cause for a lot of additional support time for Atlassian to allow customers to upgrade osuser schema to atlassian-user, because the method that is required to do this [here|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/How+to+Improve+User+Search+Performance] indicates you should overwrite atlassian-user.xml.

The problem with this method or even adding the hibernate element to the config manually is that whenever you update to the latest confluence war you could very easily forget about this configuration.

Outside of the database connection information itself (which is not stored in atlassian-user.xml), there doesn't seem to be any reason to keep this information in a local config file when it could easily be stored in the confluence database. At the very least it would seem that this config file should be stored in confluence.home dir to keep it from being overwritten during an upgrade. You could take this so far as to say that any customer-specific configuration should be either stored in confluence.home or in the database to avoid issues when customers are upgrading to a later version of confluence.
fields.summary: Simplify user management configuration by integrating it into Confluence administration area

With a few hundred LDAP groups, the existing pager beocomes a cumbersome behemoth to negotiate.  

I thought I raised this but can't find it to another issue,  heres the list:

1. Confluence provides a 'next' button but no 'end' button forcing paging through, oh 25 pages of groups
-2. Confluence does not differentiate between read-only groups (which are interesting but sometimes I don't care about), I cannot just skip to confluence managed groups.-
3. Confluence doesn't allow me do type in the group I'm after, If I know the group why would I want to page through 20+ pages ? a Nice AJAX interface with results auto-filling please!
-4. Confluence does not remember where I was in the group list browser and goes to the start of the list (chorus of 'Noooo' from my fellow users), can you imagine how much pain is involved in try to delete say a dozed confluence groups with 25pages to wade through after every operation?  Gah!-

So, some work here would make the group browser usable, currently its there as a last resort due to effort involved in navigating large numbers of LDAP groups.  Hitting any of the above points would help reduce the pain.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-9126].
  {panel}

The text displayed when using the personalised content macros need to customisable, as the UI elements they refer to are not necessarily present:

- {{spaces:my}}: there is no _All_ tab when using the My version of the macro
- {{favpages}}: the (*) icon may not be at the top right of the page if the layout of the page is customised (for example, we have a variety of personalisation options presented in a Personalise menu instead).

This fixed text is confusing to new wiki users.  If they have not created any favourite pages or spaces yet, they will not be able to see where to go to do so.  Coupled with shortcomings in the Browse alphabetically (eg, no all pages, defaults to pages beginning with A, rather than all pages) and by hierarchy (treeview should default to expanded) functions which both hinder content navigation, this is a negative experience when trying to increase wiki adoption.  It is also usually one of the first obstacles a new user has to face, and, well, first impressions do last (especially with non-technical users) ...
fields.summary: Allow customisation of default text for Favourite Pages and Spaces macros on dashboard to match layout customisations

fields.description:
In https://support.atlassian.com/browse/CSP-10738 it was stated that the solution for the NullPointerException when migrating users with null passwords from osuser to atlassian-user was to populate the password field with some arbitrary value. The reason those users had null passwords, is that the confluence API allows them to be created with null passwords, so this is definitely a bug in the migration utility, because the migration utility must be able to migrate users that were created with the confluence API (specifically com.atlassian.user.UserManager in this case, but am pretty sure userAccessor in user-atlassian API also lets you create users without a password).

Support issue relating to bug: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/CSP-10738
fields.summary: Confluence API supports adding user with null password, but users will null passwords produce NullPointerException when using the osuser to atlassian-user migration utility jsp

fields.description:
I had this problem when I was using osuser.xml, and fixed it by adding the java.naming.referral=follow as a property in the XML.  Recently I was made aware that atlassian-user.xml is the replacement for osuser.xml.  Strange then, that I cannot set arbitrary properties as I could with osuser.xml, so the solution applied to osuser.xml no longer works.  There is no current way to include a new attribute for the environement, such as for the java.naming.referral flag.

I've raised this through support, the advice is to supply -D java.naming.referral=follow through the command line to the application server.  This  should work, *if* the InitialContext is created from a combination of system environment and atlassian-user.xml content, but this doesn't appear to be the case (I just tried).  I'm open to other suggestions.

My reported environment from jboss startup was:
{code}
JAVA_OPTS: -Dprogram.name=runNode2.sh -server  -Djavax.net.ssl.trustStore=/etc/ssl/my_keystore.jks -Djavax.net.ssl.trustStorePassword=stuff -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote -Djava.naming.referral=follow -Xrunjdwp:transport=dt_socket,address=8701,server=y,suspend=n -Djava.awt.headless=true -XX:MaxPermSize=256m -XX:PermSize=256m -Xms128m -Xmx512m -Dsun.rmi.dgc.client.gcInterval=3600000 -Dsun.rmi.dgc.server.gcInterval=3600000 -Djava.net.preferIPv4Stack=true
{code}

JIRA has this [fixed|http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/ldap.html].  I'm asking for confluence to support this through atlassian-user.xml, it seems strange that as a 'future' configuration its missing this.

As a result every auth lookup generates a stack, I cannot seem to edit user groups, which is a pretty big problem.

Workaround is to go back to osuser.xml ?
fields.summary: Confluence LDAP (atlassian-user.xml) should support referral property
